Definition: In this task, you will be given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. You have to determine whether it is plausible for the Head to desire the Tail or not. In this task, desire means desires of sentient entities. For example, doctors likely desire to cure a patient. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
Domains: Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Social Commonsense

Positive Examples.explanation: This is a good example. The Head desires the Tail.

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX accepts the offer<sep>Tail: smiles
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, "PersonX accepts the offer desires smiles" doesn't make sense. So the output should be"No".
In this example, the person desires breakdance. Thus, this example should be classified as "Yes".

Negative Examples.input: Head: PersonX affords PersonY protection<sep>Tail: gets involved
Negative Examples.explanation: In this example, "PersonX affords PersonY protection desires getting involved" doesn't make sense. To have a positive answer, the Head should be an entity. So the output should be "No".
The person desires being promoted in the job, and the output should be "Yes".

Instances.input: Head: PersonX answers the door<sep>Tail: joyful
Head: PersonX adjusts spacing as well as minimizing<sep>Tail: ALLIGNMENT TO AREA
Head: PersonX also ordered ___<sep>Tail: have the dish
Head: PersonX asks PersonX's grandma<sep>Tail: to try out their grandma's advice
Head: PersonX answers PersonY's letter<sep>Tail: busts his pen
